text:
TORI DUNLAP: Hi,
Harvard Business Review.
My name is Tori Dunlap.

I'm the founder
of Her First 100K

and the host of the
Financial Feminist podcast.

And today, I'm here
with tips and tricks

on how to succeed in your
first job out of college.

So I was in your shoes
just a few short years ago.

I graduated in 2016
with dual degrees,

a BS in Organizational
Communication
and a BA in Theater.

No, I did not study
finance or business.

Like most graduates,
I was trying

to navigate the
corporate world, trying

to figure out how to
stand out while also
hustling my butt off.

But in addition, I was
actually the youngest manager
of a company of 5,000 employees.

I was the head of marketing
communication for a Fortune 500
company as a 22-year-old.

Here are a few of the tips and
tricks I used to stand out.

Number one, set
expectations with your boss
as soon as you can.

Your first month on
the job is a great time

to connect with your boss to
figure out what you should
be doing big picture-wise.
What does this role look like?

How can you contribute
to the company
and the success of the company?

Your day to day expectations are
something that you should also
figure out.

Are you expected to stay
as long as your boss?
What meetings should you attend?

These are all good
ideas to figure out
what your expectations are.

Number two, get to
know your coworkers,

and figure out how you
can add value to them.

One of the first things I did
when I started a new job is I

made coffee dates with every
single member of my team.

I would take notes
on our conversation,

not just about their
day to day tasks

and what they did in
their jobs, but also

how I could help them out and
how I could contribute and add

value, not just to the overall
company, but also to them
as individuals.

Number three, bond
outside the office.

Don't be afraid
to ask a coworker
to go to lunch with you.

Getting a coffee during the
day or going out for happy hour

is a great way to learn
more about the organization
and bond with your coworkers.

Especially when you first
start out your career,

can be really
intimidating getting
to know your other coworkers.

But be brave, and ask
them out to lunch.

One of my favorite tips, ask for
feedback, and then act on it.

In that very first
meeting with your boss,

you want to set up formal
times to talk about your work

performance as well
as get feedback.

The last thing you
want is to feel

like you're doing
a good job only

to get negative feedback when
performance review time comes.

Let your boss and
other coworkers

know that you're
eager for feedback

because you're excited
to grow and learn more.

And then when you actually
get that feedback, act on it.

I personally have a hard
time taking feedback.

It's very hard to not feel like
it's a personal attack on me,
but feedback is just about that.

It's feedback on your
work performance,

and use it to grow and adjust
and become a better employee.

And last but not least,
always learn something new.

When I was working corporate,
I set aside Friday afternoons

as my learning time, both
because, to be honest,

my head was somewhere
else most of the time,

and also because I really
wanted to make sure

I was incorporating active times
to learn throughout my week.

Whether this learning is from
something like on the job

training, reading a
book about your work,

or just taking, again, another
employee out for coffee

to learn more about who
they are and what they do,

this is a great
time to strengthen

your understanding
of the company

as well as expand
on your learning.

This is also a great time
to ask your boss if there's

a discretionary budget
specifically set aside

for learning, whether that's
courses, going to webinars,

or maybe even
attending a conference.

Ultimately, your first
experience out of college,
you're there to learn.
You're there to grow.

Ask a lot of really
good questions.

Don't be afraid
of looking silly.

It's good and important
that you get the answers

that you need in order to be
as successful as possible.

Although you may not have
the experience on paper

that a lot of your
coworkers do, I

promise that you have more
hustle than anyone else.

And the way you can
show that hustle

is by constantly providing
innovative ideas,

getting good feedback
and taking it to heart,

and asking always how
you can provide value,

not just for the organization,
but for individual people
at the company.

Using these strategies
is a great way

to stand out as
an employee, even

if you're in your first
job out of school.

If you like this content,
subscribe to Harvard Business
Review for more.
